ratings.comment: I took African100 and inevitably had to drop the class. I attended every class and still received a 0% for attendance and when I asked to talk about it, he responded with "are you done?" and walked away. It wasn't until I dropped the class that he responded to my numerous emails and said "we were going to accommodate, but you already dropped."

AVOID REGINOLD. Genuinely awful professor. Grading requirements were vague and often required students to read his mind as to what he was looking for. This led to harsh grading, and at times, condescending feedback. "Lectures" some weeks consisted of being asked to watch full documentaries or complete certificates on LinkedIn Learning. Very bad.

Very passive-aggressive/condescending person. He and the TA are also very harsh graders. Make sure you budget lots of time for completing long readings, watching documentaries, and completing Linkedin certificates. Quizzes are very confusing even if you do the readings and watch lectures, but other assignments/projects aren't too difficult.

Terrible professor. The course modules are incredibly disorganized and confusing. The professor's lectures are just basic overviews, lasting only about ten minutes, but then he expects us to watch three hours of videos on LinkedIn Learning to teach ourselves. It's just awful. It's hard to imagine this person is a professor at UW-Madison.

It is an online course this semester for 3 credits. Really confusing modules including messy assignment and poor organization. Can not figure out why there is prof like him existing in top 50 US universities while we pay them so much each year.

African 100: The course itself was very all over the place and the professor essentially just mooched off several different professors for the course material- close to none was his own. On top of this, he is very condescending. Then, he'd be shocked and angry when no one wanted to volunteer anymore. Finally, our grade was based on unclear quizzes.

He has a demeaning attitude. Lots of reading and you are graded on very few things meaning you better do well on the things you're assigned. His lectures are essentially useless as they never teach you anything new or anything you need for tests. I'm sure he might be a good guy, just not the best professor.

REVIEW FOR AFRICAN 100: Reginold Royston is not only just a terrible person, he's an even worse professor. I've learned nothing about Africa while taking this class. I've never seen such low grades in an intro class.
never again he's rude and so is his TA Dami.

Grade based on 
- attendance (lecture and discussion)
- midterm and cumulative final
- weekly quizzes on reading/ video lectures

He is demeaning, condescending, and very blunt. The readings and videos (if done correctly) would have take forever. The quizzes were said to be "straight forward", but they really were not.

Royston assigns tons of readings, but if you skim them for key ideas you'll be fine in class discussion. A few quizzes and a final project & one longer midterm paper, but assigned with plenty of notice and criteria is clear. Royston actually reads through your work & gives meaningful feedback. Class very easy yet very interesting.

Expectations are vague. Very judgemental of opinions but also wants students to share their opinions therefore it feels that you have to say what he wants you to say. The course organization is a bit messy (old links) and the content is out of date. As someone who talks about inclusivity, he does not foster that environment.

Supremely vague in his expectations. Something is due on one day, nothing else is written, but he expects you to have it done much earlier because it was communicated by ... Idk, osmosis? For someone who's obsessed with effort as reflected by Big Brother surveillance stats, he is certainly dialing it in and using materials from years past.
Dr. Royston is a nice person, but not a good instructor. His feedback is generally vague and grades harsh. Lectures are boring too!! Take someone else if you have a chance

This was my favorite class I took this semester. There are 2 harder assignments for communication B, but for the most part, homework was just readings that you could get away with skimming if necessary. The subject matter is very interesting, and the class is mostly discussion-based.

This class had a rare combination of being incredibly interesting and also fairly easy. There are two major assignments that are on the more difficult side, but the majority of the class is just completing academic readings for homework and discussing them in class. The discussions are all fascinating, and Professor Royston really makes you think.
